鱼眼摄影：快速指南（+5 个技巧）一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是西蒙·邦德。

本文由 Simon Bond 和 Jaymes Dempsey 于 2024 年 4 月更新。

如果您想拍摄超出人眼所能看到的令人惊叹的照片，那么使用鱼眼镜头就不会出错。

鱼眼照片看起来不太自然，但这不是重点；使用鱼眼镜头，您可以创建令人费解的、广阔的图像，充满引人注目的效果。

在这篇文章中，我将分享您需要了解的有关鱼眼摄影的所有信息。首先，我给出鱼眼镜头的基本定义，并讨论这种类型的镜头何时效果最好。然后，如果您想开始鱼眼摄影但没有合适的装备，我会为您提供当今最好的鱼眼镜头的建议。

最后，我以一些我最喜欢的关于美丽的鱼眼肖像、风景等的技巧、技巧和技巧结束。 （我还分享了很多鱼眼镜头的例子，所以你确切地知道鱼眼镜头可以做什么。）

您准备好成为鱼眼摄影大师了吗？让我们开始吧，首先：

什么是鱼眼镜头？

鱼眼镜头是一种视野接近 180 度的超广角镜头。鱼眼镜头中的玻璃严重向外弯曲；因此，它捕捉到的场景甚至比超广角镜头还要多。

当捕捉如此巨大的视野时，鱼眼镜头会产生大量的畸变。因此，鱼眼图像的边缘明显弯曲：

一般来说，失真是有问题的——但鱼眼摄影师努力接受失真效果。事实上，鱼眼摄影就是捕捉独特的视角和构图。如果您痴迷于创建自然的照片，则不应使用鱼眼镜头。相反，您应该使用鱼眼镜头来创建艺术、引人注目的图像！

与大多数标准镜头不同，鱼眼镜头具有球状前元件。因此，您不能在鱼眼镜头上使用常规镜头盖，也不能使用标准滤镜。这些配件专为具有相对平坦的前部元件的非鱼眼镜头而设计，并且它们根本不适合鱼眼镜头。

请注意，您可以选择定焦或变焦鱼眼镜头。大多数鱼眼镜头都是定焦镜头，通常提供 f/2.8 最大光圈和 8 毫米或 15 毫米焦距。制造商确实销售一些变焦鱼眼镜头，它们具有较小的最大光圈 (f/4)，但由于变焦范围大，因此提供了更大的灵活性。

圆形与对角线鱼眼镜头

一般来说，鱼眼镜头分为两类：圆形和对角线。

圆形鱼眼镜头无法覆盖整个相机传感器。相反，它们覆盖传感器的一部分以生成圆形图像，这会导致每个文件周围出现黑框，如下所示：

另一方面，对角鱼眼镜头的设计目的是覆盖整个相机传感器。使用对角鱼眼镜头拍摄的图像的边缘会严重扭曲，但画面将包含整个细节，如下所示：

两种类型的鱼眼镜头都可以产生引人注目的图像，并且没有哪一种比另一种更好。这完全取决于您喜欢的摄影类型！就我个人而言，我喜欢使用对角鱼眼镜头，但选择取决于您。

什么时候应该使用鱼眼镜头？

鱼眼镜头是捕捉令人惊叹的创意效果的好方法。强烈的扭曲产生引人注目的、甚至令人迷失方向的构图，您可以使用鱼眼镜头拍摄各种独特的镜头。

摄影师依靠这些镜头拍摄数十个主题的新鲜、原始图像，以下只是众多流行选择中的几个：

  • 建筑室内设计
  • 一览无余的风景
  • 街景
  • 城市天际线

但请记住，鱼眼镜头严重扭曲，因此在呈现日常主题时不切实际，有时甚至令人震惊。因此，如果您的目标是拍摄准确的纪实照片、迷人的肖像、冥想的静物照片或自然风景，那么鱼眼镜头并不理想。

因此，在拿出鱼眼镜头之前，问问自己：

我想要一个有创意、不寻常、不自然的图像吗？或者我想要对我的主题进行更传统但也更准确的渲染？

这是你的选择！

您今天可以买到的最好的鱼眼镜头

大多数主要相机制造商不生产许多（或任何）鱼眼镜头。然而幸运的是，第三方镜头制造商确实提供了各种鱼眼镜头。这些产品不仅与各种不同的相机支架兼容，而且价格也很便宜！

如果您正在市场上购买鱼眼镜头，这里有我推荐的一些型号。

对于佳能 DSLR 拍摄者或拥有 EF 转 RF 接口适配器的佳能无反光镜用户来说， EF 8-15mm f/4L USM是一个出色的选择。它提供出色的光学效果，根据焦距，您可以获得圆形鱼眼效果和对角线鱼眼效果。但请注意：它非常昂贵！如果您正在为佳能 DSLR 寻找一款经济型鱼眼镜头， Rokinon 8mm f/3.5是一个不错的选择，尽管它只能在 APS-C 相机上产生对角线鱼眼效果（在全画幅佳能相机上，您将会得到圆形鱼眼效果）。

对于尼康 DSLR 拍摄者来说， 8-15mm f/3.5-4.5E ED是一个不错的选择：它锐利、做工精良，甚至还提供近距离对焦功能。与佳能的 8-15mm 镜头一样，尼康的鱼眼型号可以创建圆形和对角线鱼眼效果，因此，如果您不确定自己喜欢哪一种，您可以同时使用这两种鱼眼效果！虽然尼康 8-15mm f/3.5-4.5E ED 的价格比佳能同类产品更合理，但预算选择是我上面推荐的 Rokinon 8mm f/3.5，它也适用于尼康 F 卡口相机。

对于三分之四的摄影师来说， 奥林巴斯 M.Zuiko 8mm f/1.8是一个绝佳的选择。它不仅可以产生漂亮的对角线鱼眼图像，而且 f/1.8 最大光圈让您可以在弱光条件下手持拍摄，并且仍然能获得清晰、曝光良好的图像。

不幸的是，索尼目前不为其无反光镜系列生产任何鱼眼镜头。然而， 这款 Rokinon 8mm f/3.5mm确实适用于索尼 E 卡口相机（尽管要获得对角线鱼眼效果，您需要将其与 APS-C 型号一起使用）。

获得美丽效果的 5 个鱼眼摄影技巧

现在您已经熟悉了鱼眼摄影基础知识，让我们仔细看看如何创建令人惊叹的鱼眼照片。

1.在地平线上创建扭曲

如果您追求创意风景照片并且不介意强调鱼眼效果，那么首先在图像中包含一条地平线......

...并将其定位以在图像上创建一条粗曲线。

结果非常酷，肯定会让观众再看一遍：

事实上，通过调整鱼眼镜头的位置，您可以使地平线向下弯曲（如上例所示）或向上。

要使地平线向下弯曲，只需将镜头对准地面（即镜头应与地面平行）。请注意，照片的很大一部分都是前景，因此请确保包含足够的特写镜头！

为了使地平线向上弯曲，请将相机对准天空。当天空出现戏剧性的云彩时，例如日出或日落时，尝试创建这种向上的效果；这样，浓重的天空就会发挥它的作用。

2.拍摄建筑照片

是的，这是一个简单的鱼眼摄影技巧，但需要强调的是：

鱼眼镜头绝对是建筑摄影师的礼物。

无论您是在室外拍摄（并捕捉美丽的建筑立面）还是在室内拍摄（并捕捉博物馆内部、狭小空间的图像，甚至是您自己客厅的照片），失真都可以用于产生令人惊叹的创意效果。我喜欢使用鱼眼畸变来构图我的拍摄对象：

通常，您甚至可以合并镜头后面的元素；焦距真的那么宽！

由于鱼眼镜头会极大地扭曲建筑，因此一旦您发现有趣的建筑主题，我建议您将镜头安装在相机上，然后只需花一些时间四处走动并通过取景器进行观察即可。随着时间的推移，您将开始理解鱼眼视角 - 并且在此过程中您还会享受到很多乐趣！

3. 有意识地移动相机

有意相机移动(ICM) 是一种创造性技术，涉及在曝光过程中移动相机以创建印象派模糊：

更具体地说，您将相机设置为手动模式，调高快门速度（通常约为 1/15 秒及以上），然后在按下快门时将相机从左到右、上下、绕圈移动，等等。

现在，有意的相机移动适用于所有类型的镜头，并且有很多非鱼眼摄影师喜欢这项技术。

但如果将 ICM 与鱼眼镜头结合起来，您就可以捕捉到令人难以置信的新颖效果。例如，您可以创建很酷的径向模糊效果；在这里，您只需在拍摄时围绕假想的中心点旋转相机即可。正如您可以想象的那样，鱼眼畸变实际上加剧了结果。 （事实上​​，径向模糊技术就是我捕获上面显示的图像的方法！）

如果您在夜间拍摄，您可以使用动态光绘画技术来创建如下照片：

只需将相机放在三脚架上，使用较长的快门速度，然后在触发快门后将相机旋转一圈，不时停下来在图像中创建清晰的区域。为了获得最佳效果，请选择光线充足的地点并在夜间拍摄。

4.别忘了进行鱼眼人像摄影

鱼眼摄影师往往会忽视肖像主题，但在我看来，这是一个重大错误。

当然，鱼眼畸变并不总是最讨人喜欢的，但其效果非常引人注目（通过在画面中仔细定位肖像主题，您可以避免模型变形）。

对于令人迷失方向的镜头，请尝试靠近模特，然后要求他们将手指、道具甚至眼睛指向相机。

或者，如果您想让模型看起来正常，请将它们放置在框架的中心，但使用鱼眼效果来扭曲场景边缘周围有趣的结构。请务必稍微后退，以使模型在框架中变小。

如果做得正确，这可以在主题周围创建有趣的框架效果：

5. 使用鱼眼获得（标准）超广角视角

在整篇文章中，我一直强调鱼眼镜头的创造潜力。

但您是否知道实际上您可以正常使用鱼眼镜头？换句话说，通过仔细调整鱼眼镜头的角度，生成的图像将具有超宽视角但失真很小：

当然，您可以使用超广角镜头来做到这一点，但购买第二个镜头可能会很昂贵。另外，即使是最宽的镜头也无法完全达到鱼眼焦距。

它的工作原理如下：

将镜头对准地平线。并保持角度完全平坦（因此镜头与地面完全平行）。

您需要避免帧边缘上的对象，因为它们仍然会扭曲 - 但如果您确实包含一些边缘对象，则始终可以在后处理中纠正扭曲。

根据我的经验，这种类型的“标准”鱼眼照片非常适合具有简约感觉的地点，例如海岸线和沙漠。也就是说，您始终可以使用它来捕捉有趣的建筑、天际线等等。

奖励：使用镜头球创建鱼眼效果

鱼眼镜头可能很昂贵，但如果您喜欢鱼眼摄影的想法并且无法证明价格合理，您还有另一种选择：

晶状体球效应。

只需购买一个玻璃球，然后 - 当您找到一个不错的主题时 - 将玻璃球放在相机前。透镜球将复制鱼眼镜头，您将得到扭曲的圆形结果：

当然，效果并不完全相同，并且您不会获得始终清晰的图像。但是您可以通过尝试镜头球效果获得很多乐趣，并且您当然可以捕捉到一些令人惊叹的图像！

鱼眼摄影：最后的话

现在您已经完成了这篇文章，您已经准备好进行一些令人惊叹的鱼眼摄影了！

因此，拿起鱼眼镜头（或镜头球）开始拍摄。

2024 年照片编辑的最佳显示器一文首先出现在Digital Photography School上。它的作者是西蒙·林斯穆斯 (Simon Ringsmuth) 。

一台好的显示器是编辑工作流程中最重要的组成部分之一，但哪种显示器最适合摄影师呢？

有如此多的选项可供选择，很容易在选择完美的照片编辑显示器时感到不知所措。然而，有些型号确实脱颖而出，应该放在您的列表的首位。在您计划购买的任何显示器上，还需要寻找一些关键功能，以及一些需要忽略或完全避免的品质。无论您的技能水平、工作流程需求和预算如何，您都有大量不错的选择可供选择 - 本指南将帮助您找到最适合您的选择！

如何选择合适的显示器来编辑照片

虽然某些显示器的设计适合各种用例（例如游戏、文字处理、图形设计和 3D 建模），但它们有点像一体化打印机/扫描仪/复印机。他们在很多方面表现平平，但在任何特定方面并没有脱颖而出。换句话说，它们并不非常适合任何单一的给定任务。

专为特定目的设计的显示器在用于该目的时效果会更好，摄影也不例外。任何考虑使用显示器进行照片编辑的人都应考虑以下功能：

物理尺寸：“越大越好”这句话并不一定适用于为照片编辑而设计的显示器。您不想使用太小的显示器，但您也不想在占据整个墙壁的巨大屏幕上编辑照片。

像素密度：这是指显示器可以显示的各个点或像素的大小。手机的像素密度非常高；因此，文本、图形和图标看起来非常平滑，您甚至看不到单个像素。虽然高像素密度在显示器中越来越常见，但您仍然可以找到一些低像素密度的廉价选择。这些会使您的照片以及屏幕上的其他所有内容看起来模糊且稍微失焦，因此您在做出选择时应确保避免此类模型。

色域：指显示器可以显示的颜色范围。一些较便宜的显示器根本无法显示多种颜色，虽然它们可能适合文档、电子邮件和浏览互联网，但它们并不适合照片编辑。选择用于照片编辑的显示器时，请寻找具有高色域的显示器。高 sRGB 值（例如 99%）固然很好，但如果您可以获得具有 DCI-P3 色域的显示器，您可能会发现它更适合照片编辑。

因此，事不宜迟，让我们来看看您今天可以购买的最佳照片编辑显示器：

1.专业摄影师的最佳显示器：Apple Pro Display XDR

对于需要最高性能且其生计依赖于用相机创建的图像的职业人士来说，Apple Pro Display XDR就是最好的选择。它几乎具备专业人士可能要求的所有功能，而且正如您所料，它的价格也很高。它专为照片和视频编辑而设计，拥有 218 PPI 的超高像素密度和极宽的视角，让您即使从侧面看也能清晰地看到图像。

Apple Pro Display XDR 的尺寸为 32 英寸，不仅是专业照片编辑的最佳显示器之一，也是最大的显示器之一。它具有令人难以置信的宽色域，这意味着它能够显示大量颜色，因此专业人士可以看到高像素图像中的所有微妙细节。它甚至还配备了特殊涂层，旨在最大限度地减少眩光，这在明亮的环境或有头顶照明的办公室中非常有用。

照片编辑器要避免的监视器

在结束本文之前，我想提一下您在照片编辑时应避免使用的几种显示器。其中一些选项可能很诱人，但我敦促您朝不同的方向前进。

超宽曲面显示器：如果您从未见过巨大、宽阔的显示器（其中一些显示器的尺寸令人惊叹，例如 49 英寸），那么您第一次看到显示器时一定会感到震惊。超宽曲面显示器可容纳您的整个视野​​，让您可以轻松地同时使用多个应用程序，而无需不断最小化窗口。它们非常适合游戏甚至办公室工作等许多用例场景，但不适合照片编辑。

超宽曲面显示器的主要吸引力在于它们能够为用户提供大量的水平显示空间，几乎就像两个或三个独立的显示器粘合在一起。但他们并不擅长对摄影师最重要的事情，例如色彩再现或像素密度。超宽显示器可以并排显示两个或三个图像，但如果这是您的目标，我建议您只使用两个更适合照片编辑的显示器，而不是单个超宽显示器。

电视：人们使用平板电视作为电脑显示器并不罕见。与显示器相比，电视的性价比是无与伦比的，但缺点是电视不太适合照片编辑或大多数其他与计算机相关的任务。电视设计用于从较远的距离观看，通常具有更窄的色域，并且可能使照片显得过饱和或褪色。电视适合玩电脑游戏，但不建议用于照片编辑。

较旧的高清显示器：如果您使用显示器编辑几年前的照片，您可能会在不知不觉中妨碍照片编辑。较旧的显示器像素密度较低，可能会让您认为相机或镜头坏了，而实际上与现代屏幕相比，它们根本无法显示精细的细节。它们的视角也较差，色域较小，最大亮度较低，刷新率也可能导致眼睛疲劳。十年前的数码单反相机和无反光镜相机可以产生令人难以置信的图像，但如果您在同一时代的显示器上编辑文件，我强烈建议您在购买新相机之前升级屏幕。

如何使用分离色调使您的照片脱颖而出的帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是皮特·德马科。

您是否曾经拍过一张照片，但因为没有捕捉到精彩瞬间而感到失望？也许图像在技术上看起来和你所看到的一模一样，但是当之后查看图像时，它缺少……一些东西。

这是摄影师面临的最大挑战之一：在二维介质中表达感觉或视觉。幸运的是，作为摄影师，我们不必仅仅依靠我们的相机；我们还可以通过后期处理调整来表达自己。摄影师处理工具包中最容易被忽视的工具之一就是色彩。

我不是在谈论你照片中物体的颜色，比如红色汽车或黄色裙子。我说的是整体色偏——图像整体的色调。颜色会影响人们的感觉，因此，如果您的图像没有产生您想要的感觉，则颜色调整（也称为颜色等级）可能会起到作用。

现在，大多数编辑程序都提供了各种用于调整图像颜色的工具，但在本文中，我想分享我最喜欢的颜色分级方法之一：分割色调。这就是我如何成功创建这样一张图像的方法：

然而，在我用分离色调的巨大威力让您不知所措之前，我想花几秒钟介绍一下白平衡，这是对图像进行颜色分级的一种更基本的方法。

使用白平衡调整图像

当您想要调整图像的整体色调时， 白平衡工具是一个很好的起点。

调整白平衡可以让您在广泛的层面上创造暖色或冷色效果。例如，如果是阴天，您可能需要将温度滑块移向温暖的一侧，使图像看起来更黄橙色或阳光明媚。向相反方向移动它，您的图像会变得更冷或更蓝。

尽管更改图像的白平衡对于校正色偏和营造气氛很有帮助，但它仍然是全局调整。它影响整个图像。换句话说，这很简单。

根据我的经验，仅使用白平衡编辑图像的色调通常就像机械师试图用大锤修理发动机一样。这不是适合这项工作的工具。

要进行更精细的调整，以便更好地控制图像的整体氛围，分割色调是更好的选择！

如何对图像进行色调分割

调色最初是一种改变黑白照片颜色的方法。例如，在过去，化学物质被添加到显影过程中以使印刷品呈现棕褐色调。后来，其他化学调色剂被用来赋予图像两种不同的色调（例如红色和蓝色）；这是分离色调的早期例子！

这听起来可能很复杂，但在当今的数字暗室中，所有分离色调的真正含义是为阴影、高光或两者添加颜色。直接使用时，您可以通过向高光添加色偏来分割图像的色调，然后向阴影添加单独的色偏。

最常见的分割色调方法之一是将高光设为黄色，将阴影设为蓝色，反之亦然。但是，您也可以调整单一颜色来创建特定的情绪（例如，通过在阴影中添加蓝色，而不在高光中添加任何内容）。

我喜欢如何对照片进行分色调：洋红色禅宗

我最喜欢添加到图像中的色偏是洋红色。就像阴阳清漆一样，这种颜色（紫红色）代表和谐、平衡、爱和个人成长。它具有镇静作用，可以激发创造力和幸福感。

当洋红色的分割色调时，我通常会对阴影或高光进行调整。我很少对两者都做出改变，因为这往往太过分了。

我通常会调整阴影，因为我通常会尝试显示图像中曝光不足、较暗的部分。如果图像非常亮，那么我将洋红色分割色调应用于高光。

没有规则规定滑块应该移动多远。然而，我喜欢让事情保持克制。这一切都取决于图像以及颜色、阴影和高光的强度。

添加一些洋红色的另一个好处是它可以去除粗糙的颜色边缘。棕色、绿色和黄色被平滑处理，使您的照片色调更加柔和。

正如我所说，我喜欢在照片中使用洋红色，但您可能更喜欢不同的东西，这完全没问题。某种颜色在图像中是否有效还取决于照片中现有的颜色和色调，因此，如果特定的分色调效果在一张图像上效果很好但在下一张图像上看起来不自然，请不要灰心。

如果您不确定如何为分色调效果选择正确的颜色，我建议您将光标拖动到不同的色轮上，看看您的想法。您尝试不同的效果越多，您就能越快地了解不同颜色如何影响您的图像。

还有一个技巧是尽力保持效果相对自然。当您第一次开始使用分离色调时，很容易对颜色分级感到疯狂并对每张图像应用强烈的色调。但是，虽然一开始看起来不错，但您很快就会意识到生成的图像具有不自然的颜色（以及明显的编辑效果）。

如果您不确定图像是否过度，在编辑之前快速浏览一下原始图像会有所帮助。另一个方便的方法是离开计算机几分钟，然后回来时会发现新的眼睛！

您还可以使用经典的橙色-青色分离色调为您的照片带来电影般的感觉，或者您可以在阴影中添加蓝色或橙色以创建旧电影的外观。享受乐趣，发挥创意，找到适合您的方法！

您应该升级到全帧摄像头吗？在做出决定之前权衡这些利弊。首先出现在数字摄影学校。它由布鲁斯·旺德利希（Bruce Wunderlich）撰写。

有人对你说：“那是一张不错的照片；你一定有一台昂贵的相机”？这是一条常见的界限，也是摄影师的挫败感。根据摄影传奇人物安塞尔·亚当斯 (Ansel Adams) 的说法， “相机最重要的一个组成部分就是它后面的 12 英寸！”

您的相机只是一种工具，您可以用来创建对您面前场景的愿景。相机只能做您告诉的。它不会单独捕获那张“漂亮的照片”。

也就是说，特定的相机类型和型号确实带有不同的好处。因此，如果相机无法达到您的期望，那么可能是时候进行升级 - 从APS-C到全帧。

我最近从农作物传感器摄像头跳到了一个全框架。在本文中，我不想就农作物传感器相机和全帧相机之间的差异进行技术讨论。取而代之的是，我想谈论是否以及升级到全帧摄像机是可取的，尤其是对于那些在栅栏上购买全帧车身的人。

因此，让我们从讨论一些重要的全帧优缺点的讨论：

全框相机的优点

使用全帧摄像机拍摄带来了一些重要的好处。当您考虑从APS-C升级到全帧时，这是要牢记的主要优势：

  • 增强的弱光性能：全画幅摄像机具有较大的传感器，而传感器又具有更大的像素。结果，您在较高的ISO上获得的噪音更少。在大多数情况下，与作物传感器相机相比，您的高ISO噪声将获得一或两间间的改善。因此，使用完整的摄像头，您可以在弱光情况下将ISO提高到更高的位置，以保持更快的快门速度或更窄的光圈。
  • 对景深的更多控制：这是全框相机通常被误解的好处，因为较大的传感器不会真正影响图像的景深。但是，使用全帧摄像机的较大传感器，您可以在使用等效焦距的同时更靠近主题，这会导致景深变得更狭窄。最终，您会得到更平滑的背景景观。
  • 改进的动态范围和颜色深度：全帧传感器可以在阴影和亮点中记录更多的音调范围。细节和颜色在频谱的两端得到了很大改善。使用全帧摄像机，您通常可以单镜头成功捕获高对比度的场景，并且您不必依靠HDR技术或GND过滤器来确保阴影和亮点具有很多细节。

全框相机的缺点

全帧射击并不是全部阳光和玫瑰。当然，有很多好处（请参见上文！），但是也有一些重要的缺点：

  • 费用：不仅要比农作物传感器替代品高的全画幅数码单反相机或无反光镜相机的成本，而且您可能还需要投资全框镜头，这可能会让您退缩数千美元。
  • 尺寸和重量：简单地说，全画幅摄像机比其作物传感器的摄像头更笨重。随着无反光技术的进步，与尼康D850这样的全帧DSLR相比，诸如Sony A7 IV之类的完整无镜相机非常紧凑 - 但对于旅行摄影师，街头摄影师和其他任何希望使用的人来说，保持其设置灯和便携式，差异将很明显。也许更重要的是，全框镜头更大，更重。在这里，无镜技术没有显着差异，您可以期望全面70-200mm f/2.8镜头可以使您重量减轻，而不管您使用无反光镜相机还是DSLR。
  • 没有农作物因素：通过没有农作物传感器来减少全帧相机的远摄范围。全帧相机上的200mm镜头达到200mm； 1.5倍的农作物传感器相机上的200mm镜头达到300mm。但是，无论这是一个好处还是缺点，都取决于您喜欢拍摄的主题类型。对于野生动植物，运动和鸟类摄影师，农作物因素提供了急需的额外范围。另一方面，对于景观和城市景观摄影师，农作物的因素通常从期望的广阔视野中消失。

升级到全帧之前要问的问题

如果您做到了这么远，并且您仍然喜欢全帧相机的声音，那么该问自己一些关键问题了：

它要花多少钱？

如上所述，全帧摄像头比农作物传感器摄像头贵得多，而且您可能需要购买新镜头。

如果您不想使用专为全帧摄像机设计的高质量镜头，则没有太多的用途。因此，如果您打算跳到全帧，则可能需要将镜头升级到与全帧摄像机兼容的镜头。 （全帧镜头在农作物传感器相机上很好地工作，但相反不是真的！）

您喜欢拍摄哪种类型的摄影？

全框传感器为不同类型的摄影提供了优势和缺点。

  • 景观：增强的弱光性能和更多细节都是景观摄影的全画幅摄像头的关键优势。由于缺乏作物因素，您还可以获得更广泛的视角。这里唯一可能的缺点是有效的景深，但可以通过使用较小的F-Stop来补偿。
  • 肖像：全帧传感器的尺寸较大将导致景深较浅。对于肖像来说，这意味着背景可以更加模糊，并使主题脱颖而出。
  • 野生动植物：全帧摄像机失去了作物传感器相机提供的远摄范围。然而，许多野生动植物摄影是在弱光情况下拍摄的，其中全框传感器具有显着优势。
  • 体育：与野生动植物摄影一样，高ISO功能对体育摄影也很有帮助。但是，取决于您的镜头，覆盖范围的损失可能是一个问题。

总结一下：

如果您是肖像或景观射击者，则有很多原因可以切换到全帧。实际上，几乎每位专业的肖像和景观摄影师最终都可以从APS-C转换为全帧。

但是，如果您是运动或野生动植物射击者，则需要更加仔细地考虑。有很多认真的运动和野生动植物摄影师更喜欢使用传感器相机。实际上，这就是佳能始终发布快速关注的，坚固的APS-C摄像机（例如Canon 7d Mark II）的原因，以及最近的（无反光镜） 佳能EOS R7 。

您目前的相机会阻止您吗？

每个相机都有有限数量的快门版本，因此，如果您的相机接近其生命周期的结束，则可能是时候考虑升级了。如果您的较旧的作物传感器模型将您的效果限制在低光中，并且您不断地对高水平的噪音感到沮丧，那么您可能会从升级到全帧中受益。

但是，请记住，责怪相机拍摄糟糕的图像很方便，但可能不是相机使您退缩。

很多时候，摄影师不会因为高端设备获得期望的结果，只是因为他们在更基本的技术方面挣扎。无论您拍摄哪种类型的相机，都可以了解它，以及其所有功能在转到其他功能之前如何工作。

您的摄影体验水平是多少？

对于初学者来说，全帧相机可能不是最佳选择。

如果您要利用全框传感器，对曝光三角形（ 孔径， 快门速度和ISO）以及其密钥组件如何共同起作用是必不可少的。如果您不熟悉这些不同的元素，并且不仔细地自己做出摄像机设置的决策，则可能很难注意到APS-C和全帧传感器之间的有用差异。

（此外，全帧相机通常是考虑到高级用户的设计。因此，制造商通常会遗漏对初学者友好的模式和指南，这些模式和指南对新用户有帮助，但被专业人员避免了。）

基本上，如果您是初学者，我建议您从入门级相机开始，然后使用全框架模型。实际上，如果您正在寻找照相机来​​拍摄家人和朋友的照片，那么一个传感器的模型是一个不错的选择。

你制作大打印吗？

全帧传感器具有较大的像素，可以捕获更多的光。这会产生高质量的文件，从而产生精美的大型印刷品。如果您从不制作大于8×10英寸的印刷品，那么全帧型号将在这里对您有很大帮助。

另外，由于全帧传感器更大，因此它们倾向于包含更多的百万像素。 45 MP全画幅摄像头将比24 MP APS-C摄像头（当然是等于！）的大型打印量要好得多。

购买全帧摄像机会让您成为更好的摄影师吗？

您可能已经听说过这句话： “摄影技巧是通过练习而不是购买获得的。”

您是否需要全画幅相机来捕获出色的图像？不，当然不是！当今市场上的大多数新作物传感器摄像机都经过精心设计，可以拍摄精美的图像，而出色的摄影师可以使用任何相机拍摄出色的图像，无论传感器是全框还是作物。

但是，如果您是一位经验丰富的摄影师，那么切换到全帧的确会带来真正的好处，以扩大您作为射手的能力。

底线

如果您正在考虑从作物传感器相机升级，请确保在更改全框架之前，请考虑使用价格，镜头兼容性和摄影类型。跳到较大的传感器可能会很激烈 - 但是，如果您准备好迈向这一大步，结果通常会很有意义。

景观摄影很困难，即使是最好的景观射击者也可能难以捕捉一贯的镜头。如果您住在缺乏壮观景观的地方，或者您只想去新的地方，前往一个新的和异国情调的位置，尤其是一个美丽的位置，似乎就像是解决方案。在一个遥远的国家公园或其他一些美丽的地方，您的三脚架和相机听起来像是创建精彩的新图像的好方法。可能会出什么问题？

不幸的是，答案足够了。天气（因此，光线）可能无法做您想要的。如果您在海边射击，潮汐的时机可能不利于拍摄精美的照片。由于您将在一个全新的区域拍摄，并且您可能只有几天的拍摄时间可以拍摄，因此您可能没有时间找到景观摄影的最佳位置。即使您确实找到了一些好的位置，当灯光处于最佳状态时，您也可能无法上班。

所以你会怎么做？一种选择是放弃进行异国情调的景观摄影，而是专注于当地风景，即使它比您可以在全球范围内找到的令人叹为观止的山脉，山谷，瀑布和海景。

但是，如果您像我一样，您就不想放弃旅行。旅行拓宽了思想，这很有趣，而且 - 如果您采用正确的方法 - 它可能会导致惊人的景观照片。但是，由于旅行时的时间很紧，因此您需要做好计划，以充分利用您的发展机会。在本文中，我将向您展示如何。

1.离开前进行研究

研究对于任何类型的景观摄影都非常重要，但是在拍摄异国情调的地方时，这绝对是必不可少的。正如我在上面强调的那样，您通常没有很多时间在旅行时探索一个新的位置，这意味着您将不会得到任何操作。您做的准备越多，准备就绪更好。这是我建议您在前往遥远景观目的地时做准备的方式：

使用Flickr和500px

在这两个网站上获取两个网站（ Flickr和500px都是免费加入的），并搜索您将要去的照片。结果将使您对该位置的潜力有一个好主意。您可能还会发现一些新景点，而其他所有人似乎都在拍摄的景点。

如果您要去沿海地区，潮汐时间表会产生巨大的不同。尝试弄清楚变化的潮汐如何影响您看到的图像的组成。有些地方在涨潮时处于最佳状态，而另一些地方则是低潮的理想选择。因此，如果您要沿着海岸拍摄，请在线搜索潮汐桌，并相应地计划您的访问。例如，如果特定海滩的最佳照片机会在退潮时，那么在那里旅行的理想时机是低潮与日落或日出一致，因此您可以利用黄金时光和暮光之城。

有关于图像的问题吗？向摄影师发送消息并征求他们的建议。并非每个人都会回答，但是您可能会从那些做的人那里获得宝贵的建议。

2.获取摄影师的葬礼

查看其他摄影师拍摄的图像是开始准备景观摄影之旅的好方法。但是，当您查看别人的照片时，请记住，光线及其在太阳升起和景点时的方向在一年中发生变化。一个美丽的位置可能在一月份的日落时可能令人惊叹 - 但到了6月，侧视可能已经转向背光，要求采取完全不同的方法。

幸运的是，有一种简单的方法可以计算一年中任何时候在任何给定位置的阳光下升和落在地点。只需下载摄影师的埃弗默里斯，并在旅行期间使用它来确定太阳的位置。摄影师的滨海是Windows和Mac计算机免费的，您可以在旅行前广泛使用它，以确定拍摄不同位置的最佳时间。它也可以作为付费iOS应用程序可用，如果您需要在现场出门时进行一些日出或日落计算，它肯定会派上用场！ （另一个不错的选择是Photopills应用程序，可用于iOS和Android设备。）

3.检查天气预报

听起来很明显，在这里提到，但是在您出发之前检查天气预报很重要。大多数旅行都提前预订，但是远程预测仅适当前几天。检查预测有助于您准备。

如果预测需要雨和多云的天空怎么办？然后，您需要确定如何应对。在沉闷的光线下拍摄与在强烈的阳光下射击截然不同，您希望以不同的方式接近景观摄影。

例如，当面对多云的天空或雨时，您可能会选择使用黑白工作，您可能会使用一种更简约的构图方法，或者您可能会专注于创建令人回味的图像，以显示雨水模糊的背景。

另外，如果预计雨水，请确保您有一个防水相机包来保护您的齿轮，以及清洁纸巾或布料以清洁前镜头元件的水。保护相机的封面也是一个好主意 - 这个封面在亚马逊上的价格约为20美元，是一个不错的选择 - 只要您谨慎并使用常识，您就可以使用它在没有开放的雨中拍摄损害您的电子产品。

4.取最小的齿轮

当您研究不同的照片机会时，请仔细考虑您需要服用的装备。诀窍是找到平衡。一方面，您想拿足够的镜头和配件来创建出色的图像，但另一方面，您不想携带太多，以至于到达目的地时疲惫不堪，太累了，无法接受相片。

帖子7个针对小组摄影活动和项目的好主意首先出现在数字摄影学校上。它是由西蒙·邦德（Simon Bond）撰写的。

摄影可能是一项孤独的生意，但这并不一定是那样。当然，有些人喜欢孤独，没关系。但是，如果您是想成为社区的一员的摄影师，则有很多方法可以聚在一起进行团体摄影。在本文中，我分享了有趣的小组摄影项目和活动的七个想法！

加入小组的原因有所不同，即使您是孤独的游侠，这里也可能有一些想法。与他人建立联系并不一定要非常参与；当然，它可能涉及面对面的聚会，但这也可能与在线社区有关。无论如何，如果您有兴趣进行集体摄影，但不确定从哪里开始，这里有一些建议可以帮助您：

1.创建或加入照片步行

照片步行是最简单，最非正式的团体摄影活动之一。这些通常是由摄影俱乐部组织的， 斯科特·凯尔比（Scott Kelby）每年都有一个流行的人。照片步行的好处是，每个参与者都可以按照自己的速度进行。总体想法是具有起点，终点和时间限制。您可以选择作为一个小组一起行走或单独分开 - 无论对您和小组的其余部分都有效。

可能有一些成员向其他摄影师传递技巧​​，这使这种类型的活动成为了很棒的学习经历。我的建议是用一顿饭或饮料结束步行。它将帮助您了解您的同伴摄影师，并且连接可能会导致更多的团体机会！最后，分享您当天在社交媒体平台（例如Instagram或Facebook）上拍摄的照片，然后在其他所有人拍摄的图像中浏览一些乐趣！

If you live near a major city, there are probably photo walks going on in the area, and they're likely free to join. Just do some searching on Google and Facebook to see if you can find some of these events.

If you can't find anything nearby or you're not satisfied with the current opportunities, then you can always create a photo walk of your own. For instance, you can reach out to local photographers, asking if they might be interested in a fun photo walk. Or, if you prefer a more structured approach, you can always create a group on a website such as Meetup.com .

2. Join photography clubs

Yes, it's a bit of a clichéd option, but I genuinely believe that joining a photography club is one of the best conduits for group photography. A club may not automatically offer hands-on group photography opportunities, but through a club, you can feel like you're part of a real photographic community, and you can often organize many of the ideas mentioned in this article.

Photography clubs typically meet at regular intervals – perhaps once a week or once a month – though lots of activity can occur online between meetings.

The best place to find nearby photography clubs is by searching social media. You can also contact your local community center or even local universities. And I'd encourage you to call camera stores in the area; some of them run clubs of their own, or at least have the knowledge to point you in the right direction.

These clubs are a great place to learn new photography skills, and evening post-processing workshops are fairly typical. Are you having trouble finding the right club for you? You could always start up your own !

3. Take part in a group photography project

If you're interested in a group photography option that also allows you to work in isolation, a group project could be perfect for you. These projects generally involve a number of photographers shooting with a particular goal in mind; the idea at the end is to have a body of work under a common theme taken by every member of the group. A project like this could even lead to a group exhibition or a collaborative photography book.

In most cases, you'll work on the photography individually, though the leader of the project may seek to curate your work in a certain direction. Here are a few examples of group photography projects to give you a sense of what you might do:

  • A subway group project: Most big cities have a mass transit system with many stations. The goal of this type of project is to take one photograph per station. The larger cities usually have many stations, so dividing up the workload makes sense. (For projects like these, it's often a good idea to seek permission from the authorities before getting started!)
  • A 365-day or 52-week group project: These are classic project ideas that involve publishing a photo on a daily or weekly basis. But you don't have to do it alone! Instead of working in isolation, share it with others, and ask them to make photographs on the same theme as your own! The dPS bi-weekly photography challenge could easily form the basis of this project.
  • A food photography group project: Everyone loves good food, so combine this with your photography! Each photographer picks a country. Then they make food from that country and photograph it! You could even make this into an international cookbook.

4. Form a photography team

This group photography idea is less about socializing and more about business. You see, there are times when forming a photography team will give you the edge as a professional photographer. The more you move into the commercial world of photography, the more this becomes important, as you can't be everywhere all the time.

Think of events like weddings, sports, or festivals. The need to cover all your bases means teaming up with other photographers so they can be where you're not. Let me give you a couple of examples:

  • Event photography: When photographing events, having more than one photographer allows one of you to concentrate on the wider scene while the other covers moments closer to the action. Think of when tennis players go from singles to playing in pairs on a team. In doubles, they have different roles and need to complement each other.
  • Portrait photography: Another great example of when a team of photographers is needed is when doing portrait work with strobes. For such a scenario, there is generally one main photographer taking the images, but having other photographers or assistants there to help with lighting equipment is desirable. You and your partner might even switch off or contribute ideas during each photoshoot!

5. Create an association

Related to creating a photography team is making an association. In this case, you're creating more of a guild, and indeed a photo team could be formed from members of that guild. A grouping of photographers like this should generally use each other's strengths to form a stronger unit when a client comes along.

Such an association might look to create a stock library of images, albeit on a much smaller scale than larger firms such as Getty Images. Other models for such a grouping of photographers would be the famous Magnum organization , though you'd likely need to keep the association far more scaled down (at least when you first get started!).

6. Do weekly challenges

Weekly challenges are a good way to do group photography on an individual basis, and you can decide to opt out of weeks that are not your style. As I mentioned in the section on group photography projects, there is a great bi-weekly challenge run by Digital Photography School , and you'll find other photography communities that run similar programs.

It's also possible to organize weekly challenges on a more local level, where perhaps you meet up with fellow photographers in a coffee shop once a week to set your own challenge, and then spend a few hours shooting together afterward.

7. Enter a photo competition

A final way you can interact with your fellow photographers is through a photo competition . There are many types of photo contests, from broad competitions that cover a lot of subjects (such as the huge Sony World Photography Awards ) to more focused competitions that are geared to a specific subject (such as the Audubon Photography Awards , which is designed for bird photographers).

There are also photography contests that require you to tell a story through a sequence of perhaps 10 photos;根据您拍摄的摄影类型，此类比赛可能更合适。

Of course, these contests can be adapted to you and your community. If you're part of a photography club, why not take a leaf out of the bigger company's book and make a competition of your own? A little competitive edge within your group can often push you out of your comfort zone and help you produce even more amazing results!

How will you do your group photography?

There are many good ways to collaborate with others and do more group photography activities. Hopefully, this article gave you an idea or two so you can become part of a photographic community! With any luck, you'll have a lot of fun – and you'll make some lifelong friends along the way.

What is macro photography?

Macro photography refers to photographing at high magnifications . This may involve the use of a specialized macro lens, which is designed to capture detailed, close-up photos.

Technically speaking, a true macro photo creates an image on the camera sensor that's the same size as the scene in real life. This is known as 1:1 magnification . So if you were to photograph an inch-long flower, a true macro photo of the flower would take up an inch of your camera sensor. But in general, the term “macro photography” is much broader. When I – and most other macro photographers – think about “macro,” it's a category that includes true macro photos as well as general close-up images of flowers , insects , leaves, food , and more.

For instance, I captured this next image of a cosmos with a macro lens. However, because the cosmos was large, and because I wanted to show the entire flower (rather than just a single petal), I shot at a magnification closer to 1:2, or 0.5x.

Is it a close-up photo?当然是。 Would most photographers happily refer to it as “macro photography”?我想是这样。 But like I said, it didn't involve 1:1 magnifications, so in a technical sense, it's a non-macro image.

Common macro photography subjects

It's a popular misconception to pigeonhole macro photography into a single genre. Rather, it's an approach to image-making that reveals the fascinating intricacies usually overlooked by the casual observer.

Therefore, macro photography spans a wide range of subjects and can be used in diverse photographic fields. A large number of macro photographers focus on the natural world, using close-up techniques to capture the intricate details of flowers, the delicate veins in leaves, or the vivid colors and patterns of insects.

That said, it's not just nature photography that benefits from a macro approach. Product photographers use macro techniques to highlight tiny details of products to show the finesse and care that goes into their creation. And even a casual photographer might enjoy capturing macro shots of everyday items around the house; here, the macro lens can tease out textures, lines, and colors that are often overlooked, resulting in arresting images.

If you're new to macro photography, it's probably a good idea to start with more conventional macro subjects, such as flowers, plants, and insects. But the joy of photography comes from experimentation and finding your unique point of view. If you want to use a macro approach to explore unconventional subjects, then go for it!

I first became interested in macro photography because I wanted to capture close-up shots of the flowers and insects in my yard. But over the years, I became interested in training my macro lens on other subjects, such as the forest floor (where I like to capture leaves, especially in autumn), snow (when viewed up close, snowflakes are fascinating!), and ice 。 You can choose to follow my example, or you can strike out on your own path!

Essential macro photography gear

Getting started with macro photography is easy, and you don't need thousands of dollars worth of gear.

Instead, I generally recommend that beginners purchase two items:

  1. 相机
  2. A close-focusing accessory

It's a minimalistic kit, sure, and there are certainly other pieces of equipment that can be useful (which I discuss in detail below). But it's the setup I've used for most of my macro photography career, and it's a great way to delve into the macro approach without breaking the bank.

Let's take a look at both these pieces of equipment in greater detail:

Choosing a camera for macro photography

It may seem blatantly obvious, but every macro photographer needs a camera.

What kind of camera should you buy? The best macro photography cameras offer interchangeable lenses; these tend to produce the highest-quality photos, and as you become more experienced, you can upgrade your lenses without needing to purchase a new camera. Plus, interchangeable lenses will just make your life a lot easier if you ever decide to shoot landscapes, portraits, architecture, etc., because you can buy lenses specifically for those purposes.

But as long as your camera can change lenses, you don't need to be picky. Any DSLR or mirrorless model from Canon, Nikon, Sony, Fujifilm, Panasonic, Olympus, or Pentax will work just fine (and there are plenty of other brands not mentioned on that list that will work, too). My first macro photography camera was a 6 MP Nikon D70, and it had everything I needed to start capturing good macro shots (though I will admit, 6 MP is a little low for creating large prints; fortunately, even today's cheapest DSLRs and mirrorless cameras offer far more resolution!).

如果你 don't want to shell out for a DSLR or mirrorless camera , that's okay, too. Even a smartphone will let you shoot macro photos, provided you have the right close-focusing accessory, as discussed in the next section:

Choosing a close-focusing accessory

Most cameras cannot automatically focus up close. So in order to capture macro photos, you'll need some sort of magnifier .

Here, you have a few options:

Close-up filters: an affordable starting point

Need a quick, cost-effective way to get your feet wet in macro photography? Try close-up filters . These nifty tools are essentially little magnifying glasses for your lens, and they mount onto the end of an existing lens (such as a standard 18-55mm kit lens or a 50mm prime ).

One of the best things about close-up filters is their affordability. They offer a very inexpensive entry point into the world of macro photography, making them an appealing option for beginners.

But like most things in life, you get what you pay for. Close-up filters have two main drawbacks: reduced optical quality and limited flexibility. Images taken with close-up filters tend to lack that next-level crispness that serious macro shooters love, and the filters impose a maximum focus distance on your lens, so you can't capture images from a variety of distances.

Extension tubes: a small step up

Next up are extension tubes , the cylindrical spacers that fit between your camera and the lens, pushing the lens further from the camera sensor. An extension tube or two allows your lens to focus much closer than usual, creating a magnified image on the sensor.

Extension tubes are pricier than close-up filters, yet they offer an affordable and arguably higher-quality option for those dipping their toes into macro photography.

不足之处？ They can make quickly switching between subjects or different magnification levels a bit challenging. And while they technically don't degrade image quality, lenses that aren't designed for close focusing often aren't as sharp at high magnifications. So you may still notice a reduction in image quality.

Reversing rings: cheap but limited

Next up is a somewhat unusual but budget-friendly option: reversing rings . These special adapters allow you to mount a lens on your camera backward. This simple adjustment effectively turns your lens into a magnifying glass, producing a macro effect.

Reversing rings offer a cheap and intriguing way to dabble in macro photography, but they share the same disadvantages as close-up filters and extension tubes: a potential loss in optical quality and a significant drop in shooting flexibility. Be sure to keep these limitations in mind when considering this option.

A dedicated macro lens: the premium choice

Lastly, let's discuss the cream of the crop for macro photography optics: a dedicated macro lens. This piece of gear is specifically designed for macro photography and offers unparalleled sharpness and flexibility. Whether you want to create ultra-detailed shots at high magnifications or you're looking for a powerful lens that can do a mixture of close-up and standard photography, a macro lens is a solid choice. It's what I personally use for macro photography, and if you're passionate about shooting the close-up world, it's a worthy investment.

While these lenses carry a heftier price tag, there are affordable options on the market that don't sacrifice quality. They're a worthy investment for beginners serious about macro photography or enthusiasts looking to take their shots to the next level.

There are plenty of great macro lenses to choose from , but the macro lens you buy doesn't have to be the most expensive or top-of-the-line model. What really matters is its ability to get you close to the subject. Ideally, look for lenses that offer 1:1 magnification for life-size images. However, a lens offering 1:2 magnification can also do a pretty decent job, particularly if capturing tiny details isn't your main objective. My main macro lens is a Canon 100mm f/2.8 model that is capable of 1:1 focusing, but I've also had plenty of macro photography fun with a Lensbaby Velvet that can only reach 1:2 magnifications. I've even shot some nice macro images with a standard 50mm f/1.8 lens.

By the way, don't forget to consider the focal length based on your subjects of interest. A lens in the 80-120mm range is versatile and popular among flower, product, and still-life photographers. I like to work in the 100mm range when shooting flowers and plants, myself; it allows me to get a good working distance from my subjects, and I like the weight of all the 90mm, 100mm, and 105mm macro lenses I've tried.

On the other hand, if you're keen on photographing insects, a longer macro lens in the 150-200mm range lets you keep a good distance so you don't spook your subjects. Doing insect macro photography with a 100mm macro lens isn't impossible, but it's a lot tougher, and if I were going to dedicate myself to serious insect macro shooting, I'd likely invest in a 150mm or 180mm lens.

Finally, for a more budget-friendly and versatile option, a shorter lens in the 30-60mm range works well for a mix of macro and everyday shooting.

Optional macro photography gear

There are a few items that some dedicated macro photographers like to use, yet they're certainly not essential for certain types of macro shooting.

In fact, there are plenty of serious macro photographers, myself included, who rarely use this type of equipment. But some (or all) of these additional products are necessary if you want to capture certain types of macro photos, like indoor product shots or photos with an extremely deep depth of field, so it's certainly worth considering.

If you want my recommendation, I would suggest getting started without these accessories. Later on, you may want to consider purchasing them as you identify the types of images that you really want to shoot. But if you're serious about delving into a specific genre of macro photography right from the start, then here are the items you'll want to consider:

A tripod

A tripod will keep your setup stable at high magnifications, and it becomes essential if you want to capture macro images where subjects are sharp from front to back.

You see, in order to achieve such a deep depth of field, you'll be working with an ultra-narrow aperture, which usually results in a longer shutter speed. In that scenario, a tripod is really the only way to prevent blur due to camera shake.

You generally also need a tripod if you're using a technique called focus stacking . With this method, you'll have to maintain a single frame while capturing multiple shots. A tripod ensures that your camera stays in the same position throughout the process.

Now, if you decide to invest in a tripod, go for a reasonably lightweight one. Carbon fiber is your best bet for material, especially if you plan to photograph outdoors. On the other hand, if you only want to photograph in the studio, a heavy aluminum tripod will cost you less without sacrificing stability.

Additionally, look for a tripod that offers flexibility so you can position your camera at all sorts of angles. Ideally, you should purchase one with independently adjustable legs that can get down to just a few inches off the ground.

A macro focusing rail

This accessory might sound a bit technical, but a macro focusing rail can save you a lot of time and effort. It mounts between the tripod and the camera, allowing you to subtly adjust your camera's position by moving it along the rail track. If you've ever found yourself spending lots of time adjusting your tripod position and tripod head angle to nail focus, this tool might be your solution.

A macro focusing rail is particularly handy for focus stacking your macro images. You can set your macro lens to its maximum magnification, frame your shot, and then slowly move your entire camera setup forward or backward while capturing a series of images.

A macro flash

Lighting can be quite challenging in macro photography. For one, increasing the magnification on a lens reduces the light that reaches the camera sensor. Add to that the need to use an ultra-narrow aperture for deep depth of field, and you'll often find yourself needing extra light on your subject. That's where a flash comes in handy.

The most popular type of flash among macro photographers is the ring flash. It encircles the front of the lens and casts an even light on the subject. This prevents shadows from being created by the lens barrel, providing balanced illumination.

There are also other forms of flash for macro photography, like twin flashes, which have two heads mounted on either side of the lens.

But I'll be honest with you; I don't like to use flashes in my macro photography. Even with diffusers, ring flashes can create results that are too harsh for my taste.

However, if you plan to do indoor studio macro photography, some form of flash becomes essential. A macro-specific flash is the only way I know that you can light your subject from the front without those pesky shadows.

Note: There is one type of artificial lighting for macro photography that I haven't tried yet, which offers flexible arms that can be positioned independently around your subject. This might be something worth exploring if you are looking to experiment with artificial lighting in your macro photography.

Macro photography settings

Macro photography, while often very artistic, is a technically demanding genre. At high magnifications, light is limited, camera shake is magnified, and setting focus can be a challenge.

For the best results, you need to pay careful attention to your settings when shooting. Here are my three essential recommendations:

1. Set your camera to Aperture Priority or Manual mode

Pretty much every camera offers a series of modes: Aperture Priority, Shutter Priority, Program, etc.

And I highly recommend choosing either Aperture Priority or Manual mode .

Aperture Priority lets you choose your aperture and ISO setting, while your camera chooses the shutter speed. I discuss aperture more in the next section, but taking control over the aperture goes a long way toward creating stunning macro photos.

Manual mode lets you choose the aperture, the shutter speed, and the ISO. Personally, I shoot almost exclusively in Manual mode, as I find it offers the most flexibility and creative control. It can take some getting used to, though, so if you like the idea of shooting in Manual mode but don't feel comfortable adjusting all your camera settings, start with Aperture Priority, then switch to Manual as you become more experienced.

2. Carefully choose your aperture for perfect depth of field

The aperture is a hole inside your lens that opens and closes depending on your camera's aperture setting.

Aperture is a key part of exposure (along with shutter speed and ISO). But aperture also affects the depth of field : the amount of your image that's sharp.

By selecting a small aperture (also known as a high f-number, such as f/16), you'll end up with a result like this one, where most of the subject is in focus:

And by selecting a large aperture (ie, a small f-number, such as f/2.8), you'll end up with an image like this, where very little of the subject is in focus:

Because macro photography occurs at such high magnifications, depth of field is already pretty limited. (The closer you are to your subject, the smaller the depth of field, all else being equal.)

So it's pretty tough to get a shot with a sharp subject and a sharp background, even if you shoot at f/22. However, you'll still need to carefully consider your aperture. Certain macro photographers like to keep their entire subject sharp from front to back, and they'll often shoot at f/13 or f/16.

Whereas other macro photographers like to create a so-called soft-focus effect , where you only get a sliver of your subject in focus.

Neither choice is wrong, and both types of macro photography can look great when executed properly. Just make sure you're thinking about the aperture for every shot you take. That way, you get the artistic result you're after.

3. Use manual focusing for the sharpest results

These days, cameras and lenses offer amazing autofocus systems. You can capture birds in flight, cars at high speeds, airplanes taking off, and so much more.

Yet even the best autofocus systems come with a major weakness:

High-magnification focusing.

Unfortunately, autofocusing on objects at macro magnifications is just really hard. Which is why, for the best macro photos, you'll need to focus manually.

This may sound intimidating, but it's actually quite easy. Simply switch your lens from autofocus to manual focus (most lenses have a switch on their side). Then turn the focus ring until you achieve the point of focus you're after.

You'll get the hang of it pretty quickly.很快，您就会想要一直手动对焦！

(Quick tip: If you're struggling to focus on a close-up subject, try setting your focus first . Then let go of your focus ring and rock your camera back and forth until the plane of focus is exactly where you want it. ）

现在您已经熟悉了微距摄影基础知识，我将分享一些改善微距照片的提示和技巧。

1. 靠近——并且更加靠近

因此，每次你接触一个主题时，都要挑战自己。看看你的镜头能走多远。探索其潜力。当您这样做时，您可能会对自己可以创建的令人惊叹的图像感到惊讶！

2. 仔细定位拍摄对象以获得最大效果

我已经谈论了很多关于微距设置和照明的内容，但我还想强调微距摄影三角形的第三个角：

作品。

您还可以尝试居中构图，将主要拍摄对象放置在画面的中央。居中的图像往往看起来非常强烈，如果你有一个对称的主题，它们的效果尤其好。

一旦您学习了基本的构图指南，例如三分法则和对称对称，我建议您尝试不同的图像布局。找到一个漂亮的微距主题，然后将其放置在画面的各个部分。您可能会考虑进行宏观极简主义，您可能会尝试包括对角线，您可能会考虑合并三角形或赔率规则；基本上，有各种不同的选择，所以尽情享受吧！

确保您的拍摄对象离背景尽可能远。

这是一个简单的技巧，但它会带来巨大的不同。

5.尝试选择性聚焦技巧

真正能够改变微距照片的一项技术是选择性对焦。当您使用大光圈（例如 f/2.8）来创建浅景深时，您可以故意将焦点放在拍摄对象的特定部分上。

6.尝试焦点堆叠

我必须承认，我对浅焦微距摄影情有独钟。让拍摄对象的一小部分清晰对焦，而其余部分则逐渐变成梦幻般的模糊，这是一种迷人的感觉。然而，我知道这并不是每个人都喜欢的，它可能并不总是符合您的摄影目的，特别是当您展示产品或拍摄静物照片时。

在这种情况下，您可能希望整个主题都清晰对焦。实现这一目标的一种方法是使用窄孔径。调低至 f/8、f/11 或 f/13 通常可以为您提供更大的景深，从而获得更清晰的图像。

但是，如果 f/13 光圈无法为清晰的拍摄对象提供足够的景深怎么办？当您处理具有很大深度的主题（例如花瓣向各个方向延伸的金光菊）或者您打算以极高的放大倍率进行拍摄时，通常会发生这种情况。

一种选择是进一步缩小光圈，但并非所有镜头都提供超过 f/16 的光圈，而且超窄光圈会导致一种称为衍射的现象，从而使图像变得柔和。

所以我推荐一个替代方案：焦点堆叠。

焦点堆叠涉及捕获一系列图像，每个图像的焦点略有不同。虽然单张照片可能只有主题的一部分清晰对焦，但一组图像组合后即可包含整个主题。使用后处理软件，您可以将这些图像堆叠在一起以创建一个最终文件，以清晰的焦点显示整个主题。

（有很多软件选项可用于此，包括 Adob​​e Photoshop 等更通用的程序以及 Helicon Focus 等专用堆叠软件。）

需要注意的是：焦点堆叠可能非常耗时，尤其是对于初学者而言。此外，在整个过程中保持相机静止也至关重要——三脚架在这里有很大帮助。聚焦轨也很有用，它允许您通过移动整个设置来巧妙地调整镜头之间的焦点。

最后要记住的一件事是：如果您在户外拍摄，请避免在大风天使用此技术。一阵风可能会移动你的拍摄对象并毁掉拍摄。然而，通过练习和耐心，焦点堆叠可以生成具有其他方式难以实现的深度和清晰度的宏观图像！

7.尝试使用自由镜头拍摄创意微距照片

我想分享我最喜欢的艺术微距照片方法之一： 自由镜头。

这个术语可能听起来有点技术性，但过程很简单：在自由镜头中，您将镜头与相机断开。然后，您将拆下的镜头靠在镜头座上，并在拍摄时前后倾斜它。

这种操作会产生类似于移轴镜头的效果，其中焦点平面不均匀地照射到拍摄对象上，从而产生美丽而迷人的背景散景。这是使用自由镜头技术可以相对轻松地获得的微距镜头类型：

自由镜头的众多优点之一是能够使用非微距镜头实现特写镜头。这是因为，通过将镜头稍微拉离相机，图像会被放大。

此外，如果允许一些光线从镜头和镜头座之间的开口渗入，则可以创造很酷的漏光效果。 （如果您想要这种外观，请记住不要用手遮住间隙！）

当然，每种技术都有其自身的挑战，自由镜头也不例外。最担心的是你会掉落镜头或相机；您还可能面临让灰尘和污垢接触传感器的风险。

因此，当我使用自由镜头时，我更喜欢使用旧的备用相​​机和相对便宜的 50mm 定焦镜头。我还避免在恶劣的天气条件下或在多尘或多沙的地区自由拍摄（我建议您也这样做！）。

8. 使用破碎背光技术实现美丽的散景

破碎的背光可以帮助您创建具有壮观散景的令人惊叹的微距图像。

让我解释一下它是如何工作的：

首先，将自己置于太阳和潜在拍摄对象之间。然后调整你的角度，直到有东西打破背光——树叶非常适合这个目的，但你也可以使用树枝、灌木丛或田野里的草。

接下来，扩大镜头光圈并靠近拍摄对象。低下身子，使“损坏的”背光位于拍摄对象后面，然后拍摄一些照片。

超微距摄影

虽然本指南都是关于微距摄影的，但如果不提及它的兄弟姐妹—— 超微距摄影，它就不是完整的。这是完全不同的野兽，涉及超越标准微距摄影的技术，因此您可以以更高的放大倍数捕捉拍摄对象。

超微距摄影通常需要受控环境、三脚架和人工照明。认真的超微距摄影师经常使用提供超高放大倍率的专用镜头。但还有另一种不需要特定镜头的方法：反向安装技术。这涉及将两个镜头连接在一起，一个面向正确的方向，另一个面向后。

超微距摄影的常见拍摄对象通常是具有复杂细节的小物体。昆虫（通常是死的）、树叶、花朵和雪花都是绝佳的拍摄对象。

但不要让它限制你的想象力。超微距摄影的世界打开了通往看不见的细节宇宙的大门，所以请随意探索和实验。

微距摄影完整指南：最后的话

事实是：微距摄影并不是拥有最昂贵的设备或掌握高技术技能。这是从新的角度看待世界并愿意接近世界——甚至比你想象的更接近。

无论您是刚刚开始还是想提高自己的技能，我在这里分享的技巧都可以帮助您提高微距摄影水平。焦点堆叠、超近距离、探索不同的主题——所有这些都可以将您的工作提升到一个全新的水平。

然而，归根结底，关键不是遵守一套严格的规则。就是要尝试、坚持并享受乐趣。那时您将发现微距摄影的真正含义，并且您将开始创作令人惊叹的图像。我迫不及待地想看看您的微距摄影之旅将带您走向何方！

本文于 2024 年 4 月更新，由 Prathap DK 和 Jaymes Dempsey 贡献。

想要拍摄令人惊叹的鸟类照片吗？虽然鸟类摄影面临着真正的挑战，但它并不像看起来那么困难，而且也不像看起来那么昂贵！

我从事鸟类摄影已经超过 15 年了，我可以自信地说，要成为一名出色的鸟类摄影师，您不必拥有一流的相机，也不必拥有超长（且超昂贵）的鸟类摄影镜头，甚至进入世界一流的观鸟地点。事实上，拍摄鸟类主要需要耐心、运气和技术——正如我在下面更详细地解释的那样。

也就是说，某些装备可以使鸟类摄影变得更加容易，所以我一定要深入讨论它。我还涵盖了令人惊叹的鸟类照片的各种其他基本主题，包括：

  • 完美的鸟类摄影照明
  • 改善作文的简单技巧
  • 大量鸟类摄影示例
  • Much, much more!

因此，如果您准备好成为专家，那么让我们从我的第一个提示开始吧：

1. 选择好的鸟类摄影装备（但不要沉迷于此）

在我看来，开始鸟类摄影需要具备以下条件：具有可更换镜头功能的 APS-C 相机，以及达到 300 毫米或以上的长焦镜头（不包括 APS-C 裁剪系数）。

当我开始担任鸟类摄影师时，我正在上学，我买不起专业人士使用的那些花哨的 500 毫米和 600 毫米镜头。相反，我花了大约 150 美元购买了一台二手 DSLR 和一个 70-300mm 变焦镜头，并学会了如何使用它。我能够捕获大鸟（天鹅，苍鹭，鹅等）的框架填充图像，甚至较小的鸣禽和shore鸟。采用正确的方法 - 以及很多耐心！ - 你也可以做到的。

也就是说，一旦您变得更加认真，并且确实想提高您作为鸟类摄影师的灵活性和命中率，您将需要升级到更具动作的设置，这也可以提供更多的影响力。

那时，我确实建议您考虑使用高速APS-C摄像头。它应该具有一流的自动关注功能，最小连续拍摄速度为8 fps。像佳能EOS R7这样的摄像机是专为动作射击而设计的，它们是专用鸟类摄影的出色。这些摄像机不仅很快，而且非常强大。他们能够承受诸如雨，泥浆或沙子等挑战性的射击条件（正如我多年来所学的，在鸟类摄影中，您会变得肮脏！）。

在镜头方面，理想情况下，您需要延伸超过300mm的东西。达到400mm或400mm Prime镜头的变焦镜头是一个不错的起点 - 我经常使用400mm Prime镜头进行我自己的鸟类摄影 - 但是，如果您针对的是较小或更多的鸟类，则需要查看一个500mm或600mm镜头。是的，它们可能很昂贵，但是有些变焦在不破坏银行的情况下达到了这些超弱点的长度，而一些最新的超级telephoto缩放是令人印象深刻的高质量。

注意：您是否应该使用500mm镜头或更长时间的弹簧，投资坚固的三脚架也是一个好主意。它将有助于减少相机摇动（在高宏伟速度上的常见问题），并使您的鸟摄影更轻松。

当然，正如我在引言中强调的那样，虽然装备可以增强您的射击功能，但这并不是一切。如果您拥有良好的技术并且坚持不懈，那么绝对有可能制作出惊人的鸟儿照片 - 即使没有最长的镜头或最快的相机。

2.研究您的主题

我不能足够强调这一点：了解您想拍摄的鸟类可以极大地提高您的镜头质量。您对特定物种的了解越多，您就做好的准备就越能捕获其独特的行为并逐步预测其行为。

从更简单的意义上讲，了解目标主题的基本事实可以帮助您确定鸟类的位置，并且（通常更重要的是！）可能在那里。

当我十几岁的时候，我的家人会去新泽西州开普梅的夏季旅行。正如大多数北美观鸟者所知道的那样，开普梅是一个热点，您可以在这里找到物种的爆炸。但是，正如我从经验中学到的那样，如果您到达错误的时间，即使是像开普这样的地方也可能是一个相对平均的位置。我想拍照shore鸟，但是尽管它们经常在春季和秋季填补海滩，但在6月下旬您找不到很多（令我失望的是！）。

作为一个15岁的孩子，我对家庭度假的时机没有太多控制，但是如果我成年了，并且我做了研究，我会避免避免仲夏旅行！

您如何加深对禽类学科的理解？对于初学者，请尝试阅读特定于鸟类的书籍和在线文章。当您深入研究这些资源时，请密切关注主题的日常工作，筑巢习惯和最喜欢的食物来源。

接下来，考虑观看具有所需鸟类的纪录片或在线视频。这些可以使您深入了解其独特的行为，并瞥见他们喜欢的自然栖息地。

除此之外，关于直接观察还有很多话要说。如果您定期访问特定区域，请考虑花时间观察鸟类而不会给它们拍照的压力。您将对他们的行为有更深入的了解，这可能会导致更具吸引力的个人照片。

这似乎是很多工作，是的，是的。但是，拍摄出色的鸟儿照片确实需要付出努力，而您了解自己的主题越多，您就越有可能获得将您的工作与众不同的独特时刻。

3.当灯正确时射击

您可能听说过“ 黄金时光”，这是在清晨或下午柔软温暖的清晨或傍晚的神奇时间。这不仅是鸟摄影的最佳照明，而且还与巨大的鸟类活动相吻合。完美的时机，对吗？

由于其便利性和强度，强烈的中午阳光似乎很有吸引力，但实际上可以产生损害图像的刺耳阴影。取而代之的是，目标是那些具有多个优势的黄金小时。它使您的鸟类受试者的阴影变软，增强了羽毛的光芒，并在他们的眼睛中创造了一个吸引人的角色。

在这些时间内，太阳的低位置意味着光将来自后，侧面或前部。请记住这一点，因为不同的角度会产生不同的效果。标准的前线鸟摄影的肩膀上有光线，均匀地照亮了您的主题。侧视和背光效果不太受欢迎 - 它们更具艺术性和自然性 - 但它们可以为您的照片添加戏剧性效果。

阴天是另一个选择。散开的中午阳光消除了刺耳的阴影，尽管它缺乏金色小时的光线。另外，您可能很难保持快门速度，尤其是用于捕获飞行中的鸟类。这并不是说您在阴天的一天无法取得好成绩。它只需要更多的计划和创造力。

对于我自己的鸟类摄影，如果天气预报预测晴天，我将随着太阳升起而努力进入地理位置。然后，我将射击几个小时，直到灯光太刺，然后回到家或回到我的住宿等待高角度的阳光。日落前几个小时，我会回去，然后拍摄直到光线消失，我再也无法捕获锋利的照片。

但是我对多云的日子有所不同。我仍然喜欢早点离开，然后在下午再出去 - 那是鸟类往往最活跃的时候 - 但是我经常在早上晚些时候到达，再待一会儿，休息一下，休息一下，然后在我称之为一天之前，请回去拍照。

4.选择快门速度

鸟几乎永远不会静止。他们飘动，飞起来和颤动 - 如果您的快门速度太长，您最终会出现模糊的图像。这很难夸大。根据我的经验，即使似乎移动缓慢的鸟通常也很快快，而且似乎快速移动的鸟就像闪电一样。

现在，您可能会问：“什么是快门速度？”这取决于您的受试者和移动的速度，但是我通常将快门速度设置为至少1/1000，以进行运动。当我捕捉较小，更快的鸟类时，我喜欢在1/2000年代（甚至超越）工作。就像我说的那样，鸟很快，我不想冒险带着装满模糊文件的卡回家。

但是，使用快速快门速度并不像将相机的快门速度表盘设置为1/2000一样简单。

您会看到，快门速度， 光圈和ISO都可以一起工作。快门的速度可以减少点亮，因此，如果您在1/2000年代拍摄，则需要以其他方式补偿缺乏光线。一种选择是增加您的ISO，但要小心：高ISO值可以引入数字噪声，这可以使您的图像看起来颗粒。

允许更多点亮的另一种方法是使用更宽的光圈。现在，更宽的孔径意味着较浅的景深，这可能会使部分鸟从焦点中脱颖而出。另一方面，宽阔的光圈也会模糊您的背景，将注意力集中在鸟上。这就是找到最适合您的特定场景和特定主题的平衡。

您可能会想，“听起来很复杂。我如何管理所有这些？”这是一个提示：将相机切换到光圈优先模式。您设置了光圈，相机将调整快门速度以获取正确的曝光。当灯光快速变化并且您没有时间摆弄设置时，这是完美的射击模式。

5.小心选择您的鸟摄影作品

让我们来解决鸟摄影的主要障碍之一 - 正确地完成了作品。如果您是初学者，则可能会发现创建引人注目的图像结构具有挑战性。您会看到，鸟摄影是不同的。它不像其他流派那样依赖复杂的构图，例如景观或建筑摄影。

但是，正确获得构图至关重要。为什么？因为它有助于吸引观众对主题的目光。它有助于产生更强的视觉影响。这是指导人们观看工作的人，以了解您希望他们看到的东西，以感受您想要的感觉。

但是你怎么能做到这一点？您如何通过提高您的构图技能来显着提高鸟类照片的质量？

该解决方案比您想象的要简单得多。您可以采用一些关键技术来改变您的鸟类摄影游戏。首先，使用三分法练习。这种摄影的基本原则是摄影师构成镜头的指南。这是您要做的：想象一下您的框架分为九个相等的矩形，三个水平和三个垂直三个。现在，将鸟放在其中的一条线或十字路口中。这将为您的照片增加平衡，并使观众更具吸引力。

接下来，考虑空间规则。考虑一下鸟朝向或移动的方向。允许框架朝那个方向允许空间。这种技术为您的鸟类提供了“移动”的空间，并为您的图片带来了生命。这是一种经常在野生动植物摄影中使用的技巧，该主题经常在移动中。

最重要的是，您可能还想尝试不同的框架技术。使用天然元素（例如草或花朵）来构图鸟，可以为您的镜头增加额外的兴趣。它为鸟类的栖息地提供了背景，并可以帮助突出鸟本身。

但是请记住，这一切并非没有挑战。当您专注于获得完美的作品时，您可能会错过单击自发动作或鸟类展示的独特行为的机会。但是不要沮丧。通过实践，您将更快地确定最佳构图。您将不仅能够捕捉自发的时刻，而且可以捕捉精心策划的镜头。图像的总体美学质量将大大改善，这是值得的。

7.尽可能地练习您的聚焦技巧

您是否从拍摄的一天开始回家，渴望查看您的图像，只是发现它们不像您希望的那样锋利？主要罪魁祸首之一可能是集中精力。当您的受试者很小，敏捷且经常距离距离很远时，聚焦将成为真正的挑战。

9.学习如何像专业人士一样跟踪鸟类

鸟是臭的生物。突然运动，或者太近了，他们走了。那么，您如何在不吓tocement的情况下获得特写镜头呢？您学会像专业人士一样缠扰。

缓慢运动至关重要。这似乎是常识，但是在发现鸟的兴奋中，很容易冲进来。抵制诱惑。

尝试利用环境来发挥自己的优势。树木，灌木丛甚至是人造的结构都可以提供掩护，从而使您越来越近。但这是最重要的事情要记住。尊重鸟的空间。

这是一条很好的路线。您想靠近足够好的射门，但不要靠近以至于造成鸟的痛苦。注意您正在入侵的迹象。如果鸟看起来烦躁或正在警告电话，请退出。

最好的选择可能是使用盲人。您需要将其设置在一个您知道将要鸟的地方，然后等待。这只鸟可能需要几天的时间才能习惯您的盲人。但是，当这样做时，您将获得一些真正令人惊叹的镜头。在此过程中，您不会打扰这只鸟。在我的书中，那是双赢！

顺便说一句，虽然您可以在线购买百叶窗，但这并不总是必要的。我曾经使用便宜的小帐篷在后院建立了一个盲人，它效果很好！

想获得一只鸟的美丽照片吗？如果您正在拍摄一个人，那么填充框架通常是个好主意。以下是一些好处：

11.讲故事

鸟摄影的讲故事不应与书籍和电影中的讲故事相混淆。讲故事是一种在一张照片中表达鸟的一天，心情，位置或活动的一种方式，这主要是要在现场包括一些环境（当然还有一只框架填充鸟！ ）。

例如，您可以在鸟旁边包含一些草，您可以拍摄捕获鱼的鸟，您可以捕获两只鸟相互作用，依此类推。如果您决定拍摄更广泛的图像（即带有非框架鸟的镜头），那么讲故事就变得尤为重要。您的故事必须引起观众的注意，因为一只小鸟鸟是不够的。

以下是您可以使用的一些其他技巧来增强故事：

  • 在日出和日落期间捕获轮廓
  • 展示季节，包括花朵，秋天的颜色或雪
  • 包括超现实结果的反思

12.捕获动作

一般而言，动作照片胜过一张栖息的照片。如果您可以在飞行中捕获一只鸟，鸟儿战或捕捞鱼的鸟，观众注定会留下深刻的印象 - 因此，我建议您尽可能地寻找动作。

当然，与捕获栖息的鸟类相比，捕获行动中的鸟类涉及更多的努力和耐心。但是，有了一点练习和毅力，您就可以成为一名强大的动作鸟摄影师。

以下是射击鸟类行动的一些技巧：

  • 鸟很活跃的清晨或午后的照片
  • 等待鸟移动，然后使用突发模式一次拍摄几张照片
  • 跟踪鸟类，直到将焦点锁定在按下快门之前（请确保您使用连续的焦点！）
  • 通过观察或阅读有关鸟类来预测行动

专家提示：当鸟儿饥饿时，很容易拍摄它们的作用；他们经常会在他们一心一意的食物追求中忽略您，尽管注意不要打扰他们并保持相当长的距离。

顺便说一句，鸟类的动作照片无需描绘侵略性和/或不可能的快速运动。您可以简单地以有趣的方式拍摄鸟类的行为！

13.捕获飞行中的鸟

飞行中的鸟类可能是所有鸟类摄影中最受欢迎的主题 - 它们也是最困难的。拍摄会让您的观众赞叹的飞行照片并不容易！

您的成功在很大程度上取决于鸟以及您采用的技术。较小的鸟通常的飞行非常不稳定，并且在框架中很小，这使它们难以追踪。较大的鸟类稍微降低，并不难追踪 - 因此，如果您想获得飞行摄影成功，请从较大的，较慢的鸟类开始。

并确保您不断出门练习，因为飞行照片中的锋利鸟需要完美的技术。以下是捕获宏伟飞行照片的一些简单提示：

  • 了解鸟的飞行方式
  • 知道鸟的着陆和起飞模式
  • 如果有不止一只鸟，当一只飞行时，其余的可能会效仿
  • 跟踪鸟片刻，让相机在按下快门之前获得焦点
  • 使用光圈优先级，因此您不必担心更改光线条件

14.背景使图片

在鸟类摄影中，主题很重要 - 但背景也很重要。当背景干净并补充鸟时，鸟照片看起来很漂亮。但是，当背景凌乱或分散注意力时，即使鸟本身看起来很棒，镜头通常会失败。

根据我的经验，对于初学者来说，这通常很难理解。他们认为一只伟大的鸟会拍出一张很棒的照片，而实际上，整个框架很重要，其中包括背景。

最重要的是：在拍摄鸟的照片时，请密切关注背景。这是您可以遵循的一些简单提示：

  • 背景朴素且无聊时避免拍摄鸟儿照片
  • 如果您不喜欢背景，请等待鸟更改位置或调整角度，直到获得有趣的背景
  • 选择最大的孔值值以稍微或完全失去焦点，以稍微或完全丢弃背景

通过思考背景来开始每个鸟类摄影会议也很有帮助。这样一来，您就不会到位，直到您知道可以捕捉出一种良好，干净的背景，从而突出鸟。

另一个提示：后处理可以帮助您解决这个问题 - 您可以清理鸟后面的小小的干扰 - 但是太严重地依靠它并不好。大量处理将开始变得明显。另外，如果您总是想着自己，“没什么大不了的，我总是可以使用Photoshop”，它将阻止您学习如何在相机中获得出色的背景（这绝对是一项派上用场的技能！）。

16.捕获一些环保鸟照片

大多数鸟类摄影师努力捕捉特写肖像。这是我第一次开始拍摄鸟类时对创建的兴趣，这是我今天仍然喜欢做的事情。

        Lightroom为您提供了一百万和一种完成大多数照片编辑的方法；毕竟，有选择很重要！没有两张照片是相同的，因此也没有两次编辑是相同的。

        但是，在纠正肤色时，我经常喜欢使用Lightroom的颜色曲线。在本文中，我将向您展示我的意思 - 以及如何使用颜色曲线来处理自己的图像中的肤色。

        By the time you're done reading, you'll be able to measure RGB skin tone numbers to give you a general idea of the edits your photo needs, and you'll know how to handle any and all color issues using Lightroom's color curves 。 Here's the sample image that I use for color correction throughout the article, just so you can see what you can achieve:

        听起来不错？ Then let's dive right in!

        How to find RGB numbers in Lightroom

        The image below came out of the camera with a pretty good white balance and skin tone. Look to the histogram in the upper right-hand corner. Do you see those numbers under the histogram? Those are Red, Green, and Blue (RGB) numbers, and they correspond to the child's forehead:

        I'm guessing you're already familiar with RGB values, but if not, here are the basics:

        1. Every pixel in your image is made up of three colors: red, green, and blue.
        2. For each pixel, the colors appear in different quantities, and these correspond to both color and tonal effects. An image that's a bright red color will have a high Red (R) percentage but very little Green (G) and Blue (B) percentages. An image that's a mid-gray color, on the other hand, will have 50% values for Red, Green, and Blue.
        3. Higher percentages correspond to lighter tones, while lower percentages correspond to darker tones. An image with only 100% values for Red, Green, and Blue will be detailless white, while an image with only 0% values for Red, Green, and Blue will be a deep black.

        Displaying the RGB numbers for your photos is very useful, as we'll soon see. It's also quite easy! In Lightroom's Develop module, hover your cursor over the area you want to measure. Then look under the histogram for the corresponding RGB measurements.

        (Note: RGB numbers are usually measured on a scale of 0-255, but in Lightroom, you generally see them on a percent scale.)

        For my image above, I hovered my cursor over the child's forehead. I've added a small arrow to the image so you can see exactly what I measured. My numbers tell me that the pixels next to the arrow had the following RGB values:

        • Red: 73.1%
        • Green: 67.1%
        • Blue: 60.5%

        In other words, the child's skin is more red than green or blue; it's also on the brighter side but not so bright that it's overexposed.

        Using RGB values to analyze skin tones

        When analyzing RGB numbers for skin tone, look for the following indicators:

        • Red should be higher than Green. Green should be higher than Blue. This pattern is universal to all skin tones, regardless of age or ethnicity.
        • Each color should have at least a 2% difference – usually more – between it and the next number. Do you know how to identify a pure gray? That is a pixel that measures exactly the same in its Red, Green, and Blue numbers. So skin with RGB numbers that are very close to each other is going to look gray. Not very natural or appealing, right?
        • If any colors measure 94% or above, you probably have overexposure to deal with.
        • If any colors measure 6% or below, you probably have underexposure to deal with.

        The RGB numbers in my example photo of the child are consistent with expectations. That means the skin is at least relatively well exposed and has a good white balance.

        What happens, however, if your photo doesn't look so good straight out of camera?

        For this next photo, I used the Lightroom histogram to measure the RGB values just next to the arrow on the woman's forehead:

        The numbers were Red: 93.8%, Green: 92.5%, and Blue: 93.6%.

        Anytime you see a photo with skin tones that have RGB values like those, your eyes are going to tell you that something is off before the numbers do. But the benefit of using the numbers is that they give you a sense of how you'll need to edit the image so the skin tones can be improved.

        The numbers in this photo are concerning because, as I explained above:

        • Anything higher than 94% or so is bright enough that a print from that image might not render good detail in those areas.
        • Blue is higher than Green. Red should always be the highest and Blue the lowest; otherwise, the skin will appear cold.
        • The RGB numbers are too close together, which means they're approaching gray. As a result, the skin in the photo is lifeless.

        如何纠正Lightroom中的肤色

        To fix this image, you should start by tweaking the exposure. Proper exposure is a huge component of proper skin color. In fact, it's often impossible to assess skin tone issues effectively without correcting the exposure first.

        A little-known bit of Lightroom awesomeness is that it's easy to correct exposure while keeping an eye on the RGB numbers. In the Develop module , double-click in the numeric entry field for Exposure so that the number is highlighted. Next, hover your cursor over the area of skin you have been measuring (but don't click!). Use the up or down arrows on your keyboard to change the exposure until a more appropriate measurement for the Red value appears under the histogram.

        You can adjust Highlights (or Shadows, Whites, or Blacks) in the same way. Activate the numeric input field for editing, then hover the cursor over the point you want to measure. Use the arrow keys on your keyboard to increase or decrease the adjustment.

        As you can see, I've used this method to improve the skin tone exposure:

        However, the color is still off. You can try to fix the issue with Lightroom's white balance sliders, but in my experience, when the RGB numbers are as close together as you see here, it's often better to use color curves.

        Color curves vs white balance sliders for correcting skin tones

        Lightroom's color curves feature has two major advantages over the white balance (WB) sliders.

        As you know, Lightroom measures three colors (red, green, and blue) for each pixel. The white balance sliders don't allow you to target the most important component of skin color: red. You can, however, edit the red tones using Lightroom's color curves.

        The other big benefit of using color curves is that you can adjust colors in limited parts of the image's tonal range. If you reduce yellow in an image using the basic Temperature slider, you'll reduce yellow globally (ie, everywhere in the image). With color curves, however, you can reduce yellow only in the shadows, highlights, or midtones – without taking away the yellow that properly belongs in the other parts of the shot.

        Using color curves in Lightroom: the basics

        To find Color Curves in Lightroom, scroll down to the Tone Curve section. By default, it should show you the point curve, which looks like this:

        (If you can't see the Lightroom point curve, simply click the white circle at the top of the curve.)

        Note that the default curve is designed to edit the tones in your image, not the colors. So if you click on a portion of the curve, and then drag it upward, the corresponding tones in your image will get lighter. The colors won't change – for that, you'll need to select one of the color channel options at the top of the panel:

        As soon as you select one of these options, the curve will change to display a red-cyan, green-magenta, or blue-yellow curve.

        At this point, you may be confused by the number of channels; after all, what if you need to adjust a color other than red, green, or blue?

        Think about it like this. Each of the three colors measured in Lightroom has an opposite:

        • Red is the opposite of cyan
        • Green is the opposite of magenta
        • Blue is the opposite of yellow

        Reducing any one of those colors using the corresponding color curve increases that color's opposite. In other words, reducing blue is the same as increasing yellow.

        Now, looking at the curves panel, do you see the histogram behind the straight line? When you click and drag the straight line to create a curve, this tells Lightroom to adjust the pixels corresponding to that part of the histogram.

        Say, for instance, that you wanted to add blue to the midtones of an image. You would select the Blue channel and click the line in the middle of the histogram, where the midtones live. Dragging the line upward would add blue to the bright parts of your photo's tonal range.

        Because dragging the curve upward increases the color the channel is named after – blue, in this case. And if it increases blue, that means it decreases blue's opposite: yellow.

        Dragging the curve downward, on the other hand, decreases the color the channel is named after.

        Using the targeted adjustment tool for more precise results

        That's the way it works in general. But you can get more precise color control by using Lightroom's targeted adjustment tool. Click on the button at the top left corner of your Curves panel to activate it:

        Hover this tool over the spot you're using to measure the skin tone in your photo, but don't click! Use the up and down arrows on your keyboard while keeping an eye on the RGB numbers beneath your histogram until both the appearance of the photo and the RGB numbers improve.

        Moving the blue curve down, as in the screenshot below, provides better separation between the Green and Blue measurements. It also gives the photo the warmth it's lacking:

        If the image still lacks vibrance, as this one does, move to the Red curve and increase the Red channel. Adding a touch of red is the best way to counteract gray skin.

        Next, decreasing green (to add magenta) makes the skin color, as well as the corresponding RGB numbers, look just about right.

        Making final tweaks

        Once you've made your skin tone corrections using the color curves, you may find that things are better, but you should still take some time to evaluate the skin tones in particular as well as the scene as a whole. I recommend spending a few minutes away from the computer before you declare an image finished; it'll give your eyes time to adjust.

        Looking at my image, the warmth of the background plants is overpowering the subjects. To downplay it, I'm going to return to the Blue channel. Then, using the targeted adjustment tool, I'll add Blue to the shadows by hovering over a dark area of the photo and hitting the up arrow on my keyboard:

        看起来不错！ Compare the original and edited photos here:

        Editing skin tones with color curves: a few final tips

        When editing your own images, keep the following advice in mind:

        First, to anyone who has heard that using RGB numbers to edit will solve all skin tone problems, that is simply untrue. There are as many proper RGB measurements as there are people in the world. As you study RGB numbers, let trends in the numbers and generalities guide your edits, but don't try for an exact numeric match.

        Second, measure skin tones in the middle range of brightness. Look for midtones to use as a reference point rather than bright highlights or deep shadows. Also, avoid measuring on cheeks, the end of the nose, or other areas that are usually redder than others.

        Third, in general, when I'm editing photos, I look for tones in these ranges:

        • Red is highest; Green is in the middle; Blue is lowest. This should always be true.
        • The Red channel is usually between 70% and 90%. Very light skin can be as high as 94%. Very dark skin can go as low as 40-50%.
        • The Blue channel is usually between 30% and 80%.
        • It's not possible to generalize how many percentage points difference should be between Red and Green or Green and Blue. However, skin that has warmer tones will have less Blue in proportion to Red and Green.

        And finally, remember that small movements of your tone curve impact your image dramatically. Don't go overboard!

        Edit those skin tones for natural-looking portraits!

        Studying the patterns in the RGB numbers of your photos is a great way to develop your editing eye. Everyone takes photos that aren't quite right, and everyone struggles to determine what needs to be fixed, at least at first.

        Analyzing the relationship between the numbers and the appearance of the photo will help you get to the point where you can eyeball a photo and determine what needs to be done without referring to the RGB numbers.

        The post How to Create Swirly Bokeh (With the Helios 44-2 Lens) appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Mike Newton .

        A few years back, I purchased a Sony mirrorless camera to compliment my full-frame Canon DSLR. (A friend convinced me that having a small-form, full-frame camera would be an entirely different way of shooting. I value his opinion, so I picked one up.)

        After working with a 24-70mm f/2.8 lens, however, I found that I wasn't completely happy with what it offered; it was too heavy, and I wanted something light. I knew that I wanted a lens with a wide aperture, so I started to do research into my different options.

        While looking through photos on Flickr, I noticed a few images where the bokeh appeared to be swirling in a circular pattern. It was awesome and unlike anything I had ever seen, like this:

        I did some quick digging. I soon found out this was called “swirly bokeh,” and that certain vintage lenses, such as the Helios 44-2 58mm f/2, produce the effect through a manufacturing defect. Well, this “defect” looked extremely cool, so I decided I wanted to purchase a Helios 44-2 for my collection and create some swirly bokeh of my own!

        Below, I share everything that followed, including the trial-and-error process I used to (eventually) capture the bokeh I was after. If you've purchased the Helios 44-2 but you're not sure how to use it to get its artistic bokeh, or if you're simply looking for a way to elevate your portfolio with creative effects, then read on!

        Meet the Helios 44-2 58mm f/2 lens

        As I said above, I learned that certain vintage lenses were capable of creating the swirly bokeh effect. I discovered that there is a cult following for a lens called a Helios 58mm f/2, and that it's a Russian-made lens that essentially tried to emulate a famous Zeiss lens. The manufacturers' goal wasn't to create swirly bokeh, but that's what happened – and as artistic photographers, it's something we can exploit!

        Several companies made these lenses over several decades, and millions of units were produced, so the Helios 58mm f/2 isn't exactly rare. That's good for us creative photographers; since they're so common, they're ultra-inexpensive.

        Where to find the Helios 44-2 lens

        Now, there isn't just one version of the Helios 58mm f/2 lens. However, through my research, I learned that the Helios 44-2 model lens reportedly creates the “swirly bokeh” I was looking for. I did a quick search on eBay and quickly found a ton of these for sale out of Russia and Ukraine.

        After looking at several of them, I found one in excellent condition and ordered it for less than $50 including shipping.多么划算啊！ (I've seen plenty of people get even better deals on eBay than I did!)

        How to mount the lens on a modern camera

        Helios 44-2 lenses were created for the M42 mount. Therefore, unless you already shoot a camera that uses this mount, you'll need an M-mount adapter. Since I have a Sony a7 mirrorless camera, I picked up an M2-mount to E-mount adapter that works perfectly: this $10 Fotasy M42-NEX model .

        (Of course, if you use a different camera system, you'll need a different adapter, but there are plenty of cheap and effective options on Amazon !)

        With my lens mounted, I found that my setup looked like a Franken-camera:

        Honestly, I really like how crazy this thing looks. Other photographers have stopped to ask what the heck my lens setup is!

        Working with the Helios 44-2 lens

        Before I explain how to create swirly bokeh, I want to emphasize: The Helios 44-2 lens is not designed for modern cameras and therefore doesn't contain modern technology. It focuses manually , and the aperture must be adjusted manually, as well.

        I've never had a lens that was manual focus only, much less manual aperture. Instead of using a front or rear dial on the camera to choose your aperture, you grab a ring on the front of the lens to change it by twisting it to the left or right. (If you're used to that type of lens, then you'll be in better shape than I was – photographing that way was totally new to me!)

        The aperture ring took some getting used to, and at first, it slowed my photo-taking process down. The aperture ring on the front of the lens reads “16” on the left, then “11,” “8,” “5.6,” “4,” “2.8,” and “2” as you turn to the right. Simply twist the dial to change the aperture.

        The standard challenge with manual focus is trying to eyeball the focus correctly. You might think your subject is in focus, but you might be just an inch or two out of focus.

        Fortunately, my Sony a7 has a focus-assist option (also called focus peaking) that lights up in-focus sharp details in red so you know what part of the image is in focus. This makes it far simpler to get right.

        Taking a portrait? Twist the focus ring until a person's eyes are rimmed in red and guarantee the eyes are sharp in focus. It's so easy, it's almost like cheating! Many other mirrorless cameras offer this feature, too, so if you don't own a Sony a7 model, check your camera manual to see whether your camera can do the same.

        How to create the swirly bokeh effect

        I bought my lens right before a two-week trip to St. Louis, Missouri to visit family. It arrived the day before we left. After a quick test shoot, I decided I was going to use the Helios 58mm 44-2 exclusively for the entire trip.

        When I arrived in St. Louis, I took the lens into my in-laws' yard to find out how best to create the swirls. When you shoot wide open at f/2, and you get close to the subject, the background is a beautiful, buttery, soft bokeh:

        However, as you can see in the image above, the swirl effect doesn't always appear. My flower photo was shot up close, which caused the background to blur too much for the swirl I was looking for.

        So I picked a subject that was a little farther away, still shooting wide open at f/2:

        The result didn't have swirly bokeh, but the bokeh definitely had more shape to it. I knew I was getting closer.

        I kept my aperture at f/2, then took another shot with a subject that was slightly farther away – perhaps 4-5 feet:

        Can you start to see the swirl shape in the background? It became clear that I needed a good distance from my subject, as well as a background that included enough small highlights to fall into swirly bokeh in the distance.

        Finally, I aimed my Helios 44-2 lens at a birdhouse about eight feet away, which conveniently had a cute little toad in the lower peephole.结果如下：

        成功！ This shot also helped me realize that you need a pretty good distance in the background so the little light spots and details can register into that swirl shape. As long as you use a wide-open aperture, you choose a subject that's reasonably far from the background and your lens, and you make sure that the background has plenty of little highlights, you can get the same results!

        Of course, you'll also need a Helios 44-2 lens and the relevant adapter, but like I said, you can grab these for cheap online.

        Go create swirly bokeh with your Helios 44-2 lens!

        I have to say: I'm really in love with my Helios 44-2 lens.

        It offers an f/2 maximum aperture, weighs next to nothing, and is incredibly inexpensive – remember, I grabbed mine for less than $50 (including shipping). Even at very small apertures, the lens produces beautiful images. Here's another example photo, this one shot at a much narrower aperture:

        I've had such a great time with this lens that I'm going to purchase more manual focus primes. The glass creates very unique images, and I can't wait to pick up my next one.

        Hopefully, you can use my walkthrough to capture some amazing swirly bokeh of your own. If you struggle to get good results, you can always head out into your backyard or a nearby park – like I did – and experiment with different subjects and distances. Soon, you'll be creating some wonderfully artistic images!
